comment.author: 38446316@N00
comment._content: An archive website about Moonfest is at moonfest.arc.nasa.gov/

comment.author: 31466425@N06
comment._content:
This particular Saturn V model is manufactured (as a kit) by Apogee Components, at approx. 1:70 scale. I detailed the model after AS-510, commonly known as Apollo 15. (This mission was the first to carry the Lunar Rover, first the carry extra instrumentation and cameras in the service module for scientific observation while in lunar orbit, was the only Apollo mission with a "stand-up EVA" [performed by Mission Commander Dave Scott], and is also famous for having collected the "Genesis rock," a 4.5 billion year old sample of the original lunar crust.)

The launch shown here was on an Aerotech G64W-4 motor.

comment.author: 7489032@N02
comment._content: Indirectly, I made this possible. At the end of the last century, I went through hell, jumping through tons of hoops, to convince the officials at Ames to allow us to launch model rockets on the airfield, near Hangar One (seen in the background), as part of my creation of the Ames model rocketry club, which unfortunately died as soon as I left. Nevertheless....  :)

comment.author: 31466425@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gungadan1] GungaDan, thanks for your preparatory efforts. LUNAR has been launching at Ames each month since the middle of 2008.
